awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Writing Assignment Tutor Training in STEM, an Interdisciplinary Approach to Enhance Student Writing in STEM Fields
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by improving undergraduate engineering students’ ability to communicate effectively through writing.  Undergraduate engineering students need more help to develop high-quality writing skills.  However, addressing this need is challenging due to limited time in engineering curricula and the limited emphasis engineering faculty members place on writing.  In addition, many engineering students devalue writing skills and underestimate the amount of writing needed to be successful in engineering careers. This project intends to improve engineering student writing in their specific disciplines through distribution and testing of a previously developed process for training peer STEM writing tutors. This process involves a partnership between the supervisor of writing center tutors and the STEM instructor. Together, they design a one-hour training experience during which writing tutors learn about the STEM assignment content, vocabulary, and expectations.  With this knowledge, the tutors can better support students during tutoring sessions to improve their specific writing assignment. This project will undertake a multi-institutional study to identify the elements of the tutor training process that have the most impact and the extent to which the process can be used to increase collaboration between engineering instructors and campus writing centers. It is expected that the training will lead to improvements in both tutoring effectiveness and student attitudes toward writing, ultimately supporting improvements in the writing skills of undergraduate engineering students. 


This project includes a collaboration between Penn State Behrend, Indiana University Purdue University Indianapolis, Indiana University Purdue University Columbus, and the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley, a minority-serving institution.  Evaluation of the Writing Assignment Tutor Training process on these campuses will include examination of impacts on students, peer tutors, engineering instructors, writing centers, and writing tutor supervisors. Data collection methods will include pre- and post-training surveys, interviews, and focus groups. In addition, student writing samples from pre-and post-tutoring will be investigated. The investigators will analyze these data and use the results to guide development of a replicable, sustainable model for future expansion of the Writing Assignment Tutor Training approach to other institutions and STEM fields. This approach may serve as a model for other institutions to capitalize on existing infrastructure and resources, such as writing centers and peer tutors, to achieve large-scale improvements to undergraduate STEM writing while increasing collaboration between STEM and other disciplines. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this project was to research a new approach for improving the writing of undergraduate students in STEM fields to help prepare them for success in their professional careers. The method was developed collaboratively by an engineering instructor and peer writing tutor supervisor who created an assignment-focused, one-hour training for experienced peer writing tutors without technical backgrounds.

This method, entitled Writing Assignment Tutor Training in STEM (WATTS), was expanded to two additional institutions across four campuses.  During the first three years of the grant, WATTS was implemented in eight courses, repeated over multiple semesters, by ten instructors.  Writing was assessed with a modified version of the AAC&U Written Communication VALUE Rubric. Reports that were not reviewed by a tutor provided a baseline.  There were no variations in baseline rubric scores across institutions, indicating that location is not a mitigating factor.

Students submitted reports for review by tutors who were either not WATTS-trained (control) or were WATTS-trained (experimental).  Reports were assessed before meeting with tutors and upon final submission after students had the opportunity to implement suggested revisions.  Assessment of control group reports showed varying levels of statistical significance in writing improvement. However, all rubric criteria yielded a statistically significant improvement in the experimental group, indicating that while any tutoring is beneficial, WATTS-trained tutors had a stronger and more consistent impact on writing outcomes.

In addition, all stakeholders (instructors, tutor supervisors, students and tutors) completed surveys regarding the impact of WATTS.  The survey results revealed auxiliary benefits that showed increases in tutor self-efficacy, collaboration between students and tutors, collaboration between STEM programs and writing centers, and the use of writing centers overall.

A number of elements make WATTS highly suitable for broad dissemination.  First, it capitalizes on existing writing center resources, which it develops further by strengthening the capabilities of undergraduate peer writing tutors, who are relatively low cost.  This obviates the need for hiring dedicated, discipline-specific writing faculty or graduate students.  Second, it relieves instructors of the need to comment on writing in student reports, which some may not feel qualified to do. Also, improved student writing makes grading easier. Third, instructor time investment is small, since the training takes only one hour and focuses on instructor expectations of the tutors.  Training preparation involves aggregating materials that have already been prepared for the course.  Fourth, since tutors are already trained and experienced, tutor supervisors require little preparation. They employ knowledge transfer principles to bridge their tutors' prior experiences to the technical document.  Finally, tutoring gives students an opportunity to explain their reports to a general audience (the tutors) which will likely be necessary in the workplace.

A dissemination approach developed by Supplemental Instruction (SI) that is self-perpetuating and has proven to be highly successful (in its 50th year) is a good model for WATTS. Both employ undergraduate peers to deliver their programming to students and train program implementers to become certified trainers themselves to disseminate WATTS internally and beyond their institutions.  Like SI, WATTS training can be offered onsite and online.

The above factors suggest that the aim of WATTS, to improve STEM student writing, can be achieved and widely implemented incrementally and economically, enabling it to be a self-sustaining solution with the potential for ongoing future growth.

At one of the institutions, a year's extension was granted to study the potential of WATTS to support students' critical thinking skills in senior design project reports.  The study was proposed by one of the instructors who noted that student projects are usually funded by business and industry to solve problems they are facing. Often students immediately focus on the application of engineering concepts to the detriment of accurately identifying the source of the problem, which leads to an ineffective solution.  However, WATTS tutors, as a general audience, are more likely to see the problem from a broader perspective.  If tutors are unable to follow the reasoning behind the students' choice of a solution and students cannot provide clarification when asked, this gives them an opportunity to recognize flaws in their logic and reconsider their assumptions. 

Two instructors from different engineering disciplines implemented WATTS in their senior design courses at the early stage of the process, when students have made preliminary decisions on how to approach the challenges presented by their projects.

Both instructors assessed pre- and post-tutoring reports using AAC&U's Critical Thinking VALUE Rubric: Explanation of Issues Criterion.  In addition, tutors were asked to describe students' ability to verbally explain their reports and answer any follow-up questions they asked to improve their understanding.  A total of 49 reports were assessed.  Of that number, 55.1% were unchanged, 40.8% improved, and 4.1% declined in critical thinking skills.  While the sample size is small, the results are encouraging.  Further study of this additional potential benefit to WATTS implementation is suggested.
